Members of the Ministerial Committee for the Corona Virus (Corona Cabinet) approved the outline of activities in malls and commercial complexes    Members of the Ministerial Committee for the Corona Virus (Corona Cabinet) have now approved (in a telephone poll) the outline of activities in malls and commercial complexes, as presented by the National Security Headquarters (National Security Council), in coordination with the Ministry of Health, in the latest cabinet discussion.    The decision stipulates that:     Malls will operate in a purple character format , according to an occupancy ratio of 1:15 (one person every 15 meters).     Entrance to stores with an area of more than 100 square meters will be possible subject to the presentation of a green sign , both in open areas and in malls and closed shopping complexes. The obligation of the green mark will also apply to the employees in these stores.     The food stalls in the malls will provide service to customers subject to the presentation of a green label , and will not allow seating but only self-collection.     Entrance to restaurants located inside a mall will be allowed subject to the presentation of a green label , in accordance with the format currently used in restaurants.    - The green mark in malls and shopping complexes will not apply to places that provide essential services , as detailed below: a store for the sale of hygiene products (Pharm), an optician, a store for the sale of medical aids, a supermarket, a grocery store or a supermarket. In these places, the current format will continue (purple character in an occupancy ratio of 1: 7).    The regulations will enter into force on Sunday, December 26, 2021, 22 Tevet, at midnight (the night between Sunday and Monday), subject to the approval of the Knesset's Constitution Committee.    Source: https://archive.vn/Xamg3 [Prime Minister's Office press release]

The government of Lebanon plans to impose new international travels restrictions from December, 15 as part of the nations efforts to combat COVID-19. Under the new directives, all persons travelling to Lebanon must obtain a health pass by registering on the Ministry of Public Healths (MOPH) web platform prior to departure. Effective January, 10, all travellers to the country will be required to make an up-front payment of 45,835 LBP for the MOPH PASS using a credit card via the same online platform. Additionally, all travellers above the age of 12 must upload to the MOPH PASS platform a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 48 hours prior to arrival in Lebanon. The passenger will subsequently receive a quick response (QR) code which will be scanned by the authorities at Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport to permit entry. All travellers, with exception of children under the age of 12 and members of the United Nation Interim Force in Lebanon, must take a PCR test upon arrival and isolate for 24 hours until the results are available. Persons whose PCR test results are positive will have to contact the COVID-19 hotline to receive further instructions. Individuals who have been fully vaccinated for over two weeks or who posses proof of having contracted and recovered from COVID-19 no more than 90 days before travel are exempt from the on arrival testing requirement. Source: Garda World  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211220005322/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/553961/lebanon-authorities-plan-to-impose-new-entry-measures-for-travelers-from-dec-15-to-combat-covid-19-update-61

From December,01, authorities in Tunisia will require all arriving international travellers over the age of 18 to present a COVID-19 vaccination certificate or vaccine passport to enter the country. Additionally, all travellers over six years of age must present a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 48 hours before departure for Tunisia. The test result must include a quick response (QR) code. Arriving individuals who have not been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 must undergo a mandatory 10-days quarantine period at a government-approved hotel at their own expenses.
